description: From Old French converser, from Latin conversor (“live, have dealings with”).

entries.meaning: (now literary) Free verbal interchange of thoughts or views; conversation; chat.
examples: Twice ere the sun descends, with zeal inspir'd, / From the vain converse of the world retir'd, / She reads the psalms and chapters for the day  […]

verbs.description: converse (third-person singular simple present converses, present participle conversing, simple past and past participle conversed)

entries.meaning: (formal, intransitive) To talk; to engage in conversation.
(followed by with) To keep company; to hold intimate intercourse; to commune.
(obsolete) To have knowledge of (a thing), from long intercourse or study.

description: From Latin conversus (“turned around”), past participle of converto (“turn about”).

entries.meaning: opposite; reversed in order or relation; reciprocal
(logic) Of a proposition or theorem of the form: given that "If A is true, then B is true", then "If B is true, then A is true.".
examples: All trees are plants, but the converse, that all plants are trees, is not true.

entries.meaning: (semantics) One of a pair of terms that name or describe a relationship from opposite perspectives; converse antonym; relational antonym.
